procedure-definition.name: meta.procedure.abl
procedure-definition.comment: Look ahead to the procedure name, quoted or not. It will be resolved in the patterns

patterns.comment: A procedure name may contain a . but cannot end in one, unless the procedure name is in quotes

translation-attribute.comment: The attribute must have one of L, R, T, or C and/or a U and/or one integer value. For example, R1 as the attribute value for Label.

language-functions.comment: These are functions that do not require parens when called.

patterns.comment: Captures the allowed keywords before the parenthesis. Some keywords are after the 'parens' when there are no parens used
This captures everything after the parens, which may contain variables and methods

method-definition.name: meta.define.method.abl
method-definition.comment: The lookahead on the regex for the closing colon is required to make this scope end properly

patterns.comment: The last word on the line is assumed to me the method name. Legal ABL can have each word of the method definition on its own line, so this rule may not return the correct values
For the return type
For the return type
For the return type
For the return type
For the return type

end-function-procedure-method-block.comment: This regex exists to make sure that END PROCEDURE is not seen as a new procedure block

patterns.comment: Certain keywords like NO-UNDO are 'gathered' by a DEFINE INPUT PARAMETER statement.
this include must be after any type references so that eg get-class(package.type) can continue to work

break-by.comments: The match needs a space capture before the BREAK, not a word break

patterns.comment: Captures USING foo.bar.* .

new-class.comment: A dash/minus is not a word boundary, so we need to make sure we don't capture constructs like new-variable

db-dot-table-dot-field.comment: Looks for format of 'table.field', with an optional preceding 'db.'. This pattern may conflict with type names

db-dot-table.comment: Looks for format of 'table', with an optional preceding 'db.'. This pattern may conflict with type names

patterns.comment: This matches OF <table>
This matches <table> OF <table>

for-join.comment: Captures something like ', salesrep where' or 'salesrep where', when the latter is at the beginning of a line. 'OF' phrases handled by of-phrase

patterns.comment: Intended to catch joins like ', table of table2', since the first table name is matched by the begin
Matches the table name in the case of eg ',each table'

record-buffer-functions.comment: this capture does not include the NOT function since it is impossible to determine whether this is a new class or a new record.

copy-lob.comment: Has its own rule because of the 'FOR length' option, which is parsed as a 'FOR EACH' type statement

property-get-set-super.comment: This is a call to the parent class' property getter or setter

property-get-set-empty.comment: This rule is needed since for 'plain' gets and sets, there's no END

property-get-set-block.comment: The end capture does a lookahead on . so that the 'define' capture can end

field-as-object.comment: This is to capture 'FIELD x AS Object'. As of OE 12.7 only Progress.Lang.Object is allowed as a type name. If/when this changes, this regex becomes trickier

define-parameter.comment: The end capture does a lookahead on . so that the 'define' capture can end

define-property.comment: This match just gets the definition of the property; the getter and setter are handled separately

define-dataset.comment: The end capture does a lookahead on . so that the 'define' capture can end

patterns.comment: Manually capture these so that we can name the relation name properly
This ABL function is handled manually, because we know that the arguments are only tbaletable.field names, and the standard abl-function scopes assign these values to variable scopes

define-variable.comment: This rule captures just the variable name and the data type. Based on https://docs.progress.com/bundle/abl-reference/page/DEFINE-VARIABLE-statement.html

patterns.comment: needs to be before the #keywords include

format-constant.comment: DATE/TIME/TZ fields can have an unquoted format if it's something like 99/99/9999

can-find.comment: This captures CAN-FIND( until either the closing brace, or a keyword like WHERE or a lock status. Based on the doc at https://docs.progress.com/bundle/abl-reference/page/CAN-FIND-function.html

block-label.comment: A colon followed by a space is only legal is for block labels. Block labels must also be at the beginning of a line. Scope name is per https://www.sublimetext.com/docs/scope_naming.html

end-block.comment: Certain blocks have the option of END <block name>

block-statement.comment: The end condition is look forward AND backward for the colon, since contained conditions may terminate on a line-ending, which may contain the colon
block-statement.name: meta.block.abl

patterns.comment: Captures the static class before the : of Subscribe ( [ subscriber : ] handler-method )
Captures the variable before the : or , of Subscribe( [ subscriber-handle , ] handler-procedure ) or Subscribe ( [ subscriber : ] handler-method )
Subscribe( handler-procedure or handler-method)

for-record.comment: this regex just tries to capture a bunch (6) of tables

block-undo-leave-next-retry.comment: Covers NEXT, LEAVE, RETRY and UNDO with block labels that are not preceded by UNDO,

branch-return-error-expression.comment: This regex captures to the end of the line, or the colon, whichever comes first

patterns.comment: The comment scopes are included in the statements pattern, but the operator trumps these

function-arguments.name: meta.function.arguments.abl
function-arguments.comment: Captures what's between ( and ) when calling a function, excluding the braces

static-object-property-call.commment: This rule only captures dotted type name and not single class names

variable-name.comment: 1 to 128 characters; can consist of any combination of letters (a-z or A-Z), numbers (0-9), and these special characters: #$-_%& Names must begin with a letter (from https://docs.progress.com/bundle/openedge-abl-manage-applications/page/Name-limits.html)
variable-name.name: variable.other.abl

patterns.comment: See https://docs.progress.com/bundle/abl-reference/page/Array-reference.html for array ranges

patterns.name: meta.include.argument.abl
patterns.comment: This is intended to catch '&arg' and '&arg='

1.name: support.other.argument.abl
1.comment: you can use variable names, field names, and reserved words as argument names.

patterns.comment: non-string argument values after the &arg =
patterns.name: meta.include.argument.abl

1.name: support.other.argument.abl
1.comment: you can use variable names, field names, and reserved words as argument names.

patterns.comment: non-string argument values after the &arg =
patterns.name: meta.include.argument.abl

1.name: support.other.argument.abl
1.comment: you can use variable names, field names, and reserved words as argument names.

patterns.comment: non-string unnamed argument values

1.name: support.other.argument.abl
1.comment: you can use variable names, field names, and reserved words as argument names.

singlelinecomment.comment: Was comment.source.abl but should be changed, per https://macromates.com/manual/en/language_grammars
singlelinecomment.name: comment.line.double-slash.abl

operator-with-space.comment: Lookahead and -behind for the spaces, so that in particular the NOT is captured properly

new-record.comment: This scope MUST be called after before type-reference (especially new-class) to avoid types being captured as tables

patterns.comment: NEW\s+( <buffer> )
NEW <buffer>. The position of the negative lookahead (?!...) is very important

keywords-A.comment: The keyword must not have a trailing variable character (one of #$-_%&)

keywords-B.comment: The keyword must not have a trailing variable character (one of #$-_%&)

keywords-C.comment: The keyword must not have a trailing variable character (one of #$-_%&)

keywords-D.comment: The keyword must not have a trailing variable character (one of #$-_%&)

keywords-Y.comment: The keyword must not have a trailing variable character (one of #$-_%&)
